title: Why Does Lowering the Upper Limit of Judicial Protection of Private Lending Interest Rates Have Limited Effect in Promoting Enterprises’ Access to Credit? -Part 4
main_title: Why Does Lowering the Upper Limit of Judicial Protection of Private Lending Interest Rates Have Limited Effect in Promoting Enterprises’ Access to Credit? -Part 4
description: Lowering the upper limit of private lending interest rate protection is a good exploration but improving the quality of corporate financing services may require more effort.
keywords: private lending interest rate, financial risks, enterprises’ access to credit.
subtitle: Why Does Lowering the Upper Limit of Judicial Protection of Private Lending Interest Rates Have Limited Effect in Promoting Enterprises’ Access to Credit? -Part 4
content:
A deeper understanding of corporate financing issues from lowering the upper limit of protection of private lending interest rates


The starting point for lowering the upper limit of the protection of private lending interest rates is good and has positive significance judicially. However, corporate financing is more dictated by economic laws, and expanding the availability of corporate financing through judicial improvements is a profound topic. Lowering the upper limit of private lending interest rate protection is a good exploration but improving the quality of corporate financing services may require more effort.


For another example, “Regulation of the Financial Market Investment and Financing Order” mentions that “in accordance with the requirements of functional supervision, to conceal financial risks, circumvent financial supervision, and conduct institutional arbitrage violations in the name of financial innovation, determine contract validity and rights and obligations based on their actual legal relationship”, and “in time study and formulate judicial response measures against financial phenomena such as online lending, asset management plans, over-the-counter funding, asset securitization, equity crowdfunding, etc., and improve the initiative and predictability of preventing and resolving major financial risks.” This is the response to various so-called “regulatory arbitrage” in the name of “financial innovation” in recent years, and it is also in line with the general trend of financial supervision and prevention of financial risks.


As mentioned above, alleviating difficulties and huge costs of corporate financing is a systematic project. Lowering the upper limit of judicial protection of private lending interest rates is a positive measure, but it should not be imposed unrealistically higher expectations. There is still more work to be done to improve corporate credit access and improve the quality of financial services.

title: Why Does Lowering the Upper Limit of Judicial Protection of Private Lending Interest Rates Have Limited Effect in Promoting Enterprises’ Access to Credit? -Part 3
main_title: Why Does Lowering the Upper Limit of Judicial Protection of Private Lending Interest Rates Have Limited Effect in Promoting Enterprises’ Access to Credit? -Part 3
description: Lowering the upper limit of judicial protection for private lending has a major deterrent and restrictive effect on usury on-lending and lending, but it has little effect on promoting formal bank loans.
keywords: upper limit of judicial protection, formal finance & private lending, enterprises’ access to credit.
subtitle: Why Does Lowering the Upper Limit of Judicial Protection of Private Lending Interest Rates Have Limited Effect in Promoting Enterprises’ Access to Credit? -Part 3
content:
Lowering the upper limit of judicial protection has little impact on formal finance


From the perspective of channels, corporate financing is divided into formal finance and informal finance (i.e., private lending).


Generally speaking, the formal financial interest rate is low, but the efficiency is relatively low, and the requirements for enterprise qualifications and collateral are high. Especially in the inclusive small and micro businesses, bank credit loans account for less than 20%, and the funds are mainly used to maintain production or expand reproduction. Private lending interest rates are generally high, but the overall efficiency is also higher. There are often no rigid requirements for corporate qualifications and collateral, which can meet the short-term capital turnover and emergency funding needs of enterprises.


The roles of the two in business operation are obviously different.


Formal finance should be the main channel of corporate financing, and there are very few companies relying solely on private lending to develop and be able to continue developing.


Why? Just because the private lending interest rate is too high.


Almost no industry can afford long-term financing interest rates above 15%.


Private lending is auxiliary in the production and operation of enterprises, and the interest rate is relatively high. Bank credit should be the main channel for the external financing of enterprises, and the overall interest rate level is not high. Lowering the upper limit of private lending interest rate protection is mainly to protect the auxiliary and emergency financing of enterprises and reduce the temporary turnover financing cost of enterprises. Since the bank loan interest rate is much lower than the upper limit, even if it is greatly reduced, such as from the current 24% dropped by half to 12%, which may have a devastating blow to private lending, the impact on bank credit is relatively limited.


From this perspective, lowering the upper limit of judicial protection for private lending has a major deterrent and restrictive effect on usury on-lending and lending, but it has little effect on promoting formal bank loans. Therefore, it is far away from the “most effective solution.”

title: Why Does Lowering the Upper Limit of Judicial Protection of Private Lending Interest Rates Have Limited Effect in Promoting Enterprises’ Access to Credit? -Part 2
main_title: Why Does Lowering the Upper Limit of Judicial Protection of Private Lending Interest Rates Have Limited Effect in Promoting Enterprises’ Access to Credit? -Part 2
description: To break the price equilibrium, relying on administrative orders to push the price curve is often counterproductive.
keywords: price equilibrium, upper limit of interest rate protection, private lending interest rates.
subtitle: Why Does Lowering the Upper Limit of Judicial Protection of Private Lending Interest Rates Have Limited Effect in Promoting Enterprises’ Access to Credit? -Part 2
content:
For example, in expanding investment, a company will predict the sales of a new project after it is put into production. In the end, as long as there is 90% or even 80% of success, the company will actively start; but from the bank side, a project with 10% of risk of loss is totally unacceptable. In this case, either the bank does not grant loans, or the company needs to provide a second source of repayment, i.e., mortgage collateral, which is the fundamental source of the divergence between the demand for and supply of funds.


The loan interest rate is the price equilibrium formed in the game between the bank and the enterprise. Of course, since the bank is relatively strong, the price equilibrium is more inclined to the bank side, which is also the source of the high financing cost of the enterprise.


To break the price equilibrium, relying on administrative orders to push the price curve is often counterproductive.


Forcing a price ceiling, on the one hand, will lead to a decrease in supply and on the other hand, to the emergence of rent-seeking. The market will push prices to eventually return to an equilibrium position, but it may be with a higher level and less supply.


From the perspective of economic laws, assuming that the current upper limit of interest rate protection is relatively in line with market demand, even if a substantial reduction in the upper limit of judicial protection of private lending interest rates can influence corporate financing, it may be negative.

title: Why Does Lowering the Upper Limit of Judicial Protection of Private Lending Interest Rates Have Limited Effect in Promoting Enterprises’ Access to Credit? -Part 1
main_title: Why Does Lowering the Upper Limit of Judicial Protection of Private Lending Interest Rates Have Limited Effect in Promoting Enterprises’ Access to Credit? -Part 1
description: The high cost of corporate financing is superficial. The root cause lies in the information asymmetry between the demand for funds and the supply side.
keywords: economic law, supply side, private lending interest rates.
subtitle: Why Does Lowering the Upper Limit of Judicial Protection of Private Lending Interest Rates Have Limited Effect in Promoting Enterprises’ Access to Credit? -Part 1
content:
The interest rate is the surface while the economic law is the core.


In the process of development, market entities will inevitably encounter financing.


Interest rate is the price and the external performance of financing. The factors that determine the financing interest rate include not only the enterprise qualification and capital use on the demand side, but also the risk control requirements and management level of financial institutions on the supply side. The most fundamental thing is whether the price can cover the risk. What determines the availability of financing is the measurement of risks and benefits by financial institutions or investors.


If lowering the upper limit of judicial protection of private lending interest rates is the “most effective solution” to alleviate the difficulty and expansive cost of financing, why wouldn’t the financial regulatory authorities directly stipulate the upper limit of the maximum interest rate for bank loans?


Actually, the high cost of corporate financing is superficial. The root cause lies in the information asymmetry between the demand for funds and the supply side. There is a huge divergence in the awareness and control of risks between banks and enterprises, which leads to an imbalance between the demand for corporate funds and the supply of bank funds.

title: How Does the U.S. Dollar Influence the World? -Part 6
main_title: How Does the U.S. Dollar Influence the World? -Part 6
description: Since some countries have accumulated USD reserves, they will purchase USD-related assets, and the fluctuation of the USD exchange rate and the return of USD assets will have a direct influence.
keywords: foreign exchange reserves, USD-related assets, U.S. dollar.
subtitle: How Does the U.S. Dollar Influence the World? -Part 6
content:
6. Issues of maintaining and increasing the value of foreign exchange reserves


At present, in order to respond to foreign exchange demand, some countries have accumulated large-scale foreign exchange reserves, such as US dollars, euros, Japanese yen, and British pounds. There is no doubt that the scale of USD reserves is the largest. The so-called foreign exchange reserves do not mean keeping foreign exchanges in the account, but using them for investment, so as to achieve value maintenance and appreciation. Since some countries have accumulated USD reserves, they will purchase USD-related assets, and the fluctuation of the USD exchange rate and the return of USD assets will directly affect the scale of foreign exchange reserves and the level of return.


In fact, the ideal situation in international trade is that a country exports products and imports what it needs for consumption by its own people, so as to achieve a basic trade balance, which can improve people’s welfare. Otherwise, holding foreign exchange reserves is equivalent to import losses because the money could have been used for imports. Of course, in order to cope with emergencies, countries have to accumulate a certain scale of foreign exchange reserves, which we do not discuss here. What is more serious is that if foreign exchange reserves suffer losses due to exchange rate fluctuations and investment, it directly leads to losses in welfare.

title: How Does the U.S. Dollar Influence the World? -Part 5
main_title: How Does the U.S. Dollar Influence the World? -Part 5
description: Debt crises have happened numerous times in modern history, and most of them are U.S. dollar debt crises.
keywords: U.S. dollar debt, appreciation & depreciation, U.S. dollar.
subtitle: How Does the U.S. Dollar Influence the World? -Part 5
content:
5. U.S. dollar debt


Developing countries generally face a fundamental problem: it is difficult to borrow debts in their own currencies in the international financial market. According to BIS, about 70% of the current global debt is denominated in USD, which is dollar debt, and the rest are denominated in euro, pound sterling, yen and so on. If the scale of U.S. dollar debt is too great, there is a risk of default. As discussed in the periodic fluctuations of the USD exchange rate above, when the U.S. dollar debt is large-scale and the USD appreciates, the local currency value of the U.S. dollar debt will rise sharply, resulting in repayment difficulty. It is particularly important for companies in emerging market countries, because many companies have borrowed a large amount of foreign debt in USD in the international market. If the company has problems with its own operations and faces depreciation of the domestic currency and appreciation of the USD, there could be a default, leading to ratings downgrades and liquidity problems.


Another aspect is the “sudden stop” of capital flows. Although the inflow of capital into emerging markets can achieve the rolling of debt under normal circumstances, if the capital flow suddenly stops, this rolling will stop, and defaults will occur. A recent BIS study pointed out that when the global market becomes unstable, companies and other borrowers would face higher financing risks. When the domestic currency depreciates, it may be difficult for foreign currency debt to continue rolling.


Debt crises have happened numerous times in modern history, and most of them are U.S. dollar debt crises, such as in Mexico and Latin American countries, without exception. This channel of influence of USD deserves the attention of other countries.

title: How Does the U.S. Dollar Influence the World? -Part 4
main_title: How Does the U.S. Dollar Influence the World? -Part 4
description: Corresponding to the universal use of USD-denominated settlement in world trade, trade entities in various countries have a greater demand for USD trade financing.
keywords: USD trade financing, financing currency, U.S. dollar.
subtitle: How Does the U.S. Dollar Influence the World? -Part 4
content:
4. USD trade financing


Corresponding to the universal use of USD-denominated settlement in world trade, trade entities in various countries have a greater demand for USD trade financing. We all know that companies are highly dependent on trade financing in foreign trade. Take export companies as an example. The company’s own funds may be insufficient. When receiving an export order, it needs to obtain financing from the bank for production. The financing currency is generally the same as the settlement currency, so there is no exchange rate risk because the financing shall be repaid directly upon receipt of the trade payment; when exports are settled in USD, the financing currency is usually the same. Another situation is that after the product is exported, the company does not receive the payment immediately, and there is a need for funds. The company can obtain bank financing through export orders, which basically use the same currency as the settlement currency of trade.


The Fed’s monetary policy (related to USD interest rates), the strength of the USD exchange rate, and the adequacy of global USD liquidity directly affect the cost and availability of USD trade financing. According to the Bank for International Settlements (BIS), the strength of the USD exchange rate is significantly negatively correlated with the scale of world trade. When it strengthens, especially accompanied by financial market turbulence, it will lead to a shortage of USD liquidity, increase the cost of USD trade financing, and reduce the availability of USD trade financing, directly reducing the scale of world trade. Conversely, when it weakens and the USD interest rate is low, it will be beneficial for the expansion of the scale of world trade.

title: How Does the U.S. Dollar Influence the World? -Part 3
main_title: How Does the U.S. Dollar Influence the World? -Part 3
description: Which currency is used in valuation has a completely different impact, directly affecting the role of the exchange rate on exports and the issue of exchange rate risks.
keywords: trade domination, domestic currency, U.S. dollar.
subtitle: How Does the U.S. Dollar Influence the World? -Part 3
content:
3. Trade denominated in USD


We always pay attention to settlement issues, but the issue of pricing is of the same importance. Which currency is used in valuation has a completely different impact, directly affecting the role of the exchange rate on exports and the issue of exchange rate risks. Generally speaking, we believe that settlement in the home currency will avoid exchange rate risk, but it depends on whether the pricing is also done in the home currency. If it is denominated in a foreign currency but settled in the home currency, actually, exchange rate risks could not be effectively avoided.


Similarly, if the price of export products denominated in USD remains unchanged, the depreciation of the domestic currency will not affect the export price, and the export promotion effect of the depreciation of the domestic currency will also be reduced. But in the case of a depreciation of the domestic currency, the same amount of U.S. dollar will be exchanged for more domestic currency, and the benefits of exporting the same number of products will increase. In addition, under the global value chain, the production of a product has to go through multiple import and export processes, and the impact of the currency of valuation is more complicated.


There is also the issue of commodity pricing. At present, the bulk commodities in international trade are basically settled in USD, the strength of which will directly affect the bulk commodity exports of some countries, thereby affecting their balance of payments.

title: How Does the U.S. Dollar Influence the World? -Part 2
main_title: How Does the U.S. Dollar Influence the World? -Part 2
description: The periodic fluctuations of the USD exchange rate have had a serious impact on other countries.
keywords: Periodic fluctuation, U.S. dollar exchange rate, U.S. dollar.
subtitle: How Does the U.S. Dollar Influence the World? -Part 2
content:
2. Periodic fluctuation of the USD exchange rate


Some studies have shown that the periodic fluctuations of the USD exchange rate have had a serious impact on other countries. No matter whether the USD appreciates or depreciates, the negative influence cannot be avoided. The path of the impact is the tidal movement of USD liquidity that accompanies the fluctuation of the exchange rate.


When the U.S. dollar continues to appreciate, funds tend to flow to the United States, and some countries are faced with a large-scale outflow of funds, which may lead to currency crises in these countries, substantial currency depreciation. One of the direct consequences is that the currency mismatch becomes more serious. The scale of foreign debt denominated in USD rises sharply after being converted into currency, which in turn will lead to debt crises.


When the U.S. dollar continues to depreciate, funds will flock to other countries, especially emerging market economies, for the sake of high returns. On the one hand, large-scale capital inflows will promote the appreciation of the currency; on the other hand, it may cause major fluctuations in the country’s financial markets and even asset bubbles. What’s more serious is that these inflows may be short-term, just to obtain high returns. When the situation changes, it is extremely possible to escape from emerging market countries, leading to the bursting of asset bubbles and financial crises in these countries.


After the 2008 global financial crisis, in view of the impact of abnormal capital liquidity on some countries, the IMF has changed its previous attitude towards capital flow liberalization and has also advocated that appropriate tools be adopted to control cross-border capital flows in extraordinary periods to avoid economic and financial crisis.

title: How Does the U.S. Dollar Influence the World? -Part 1
main_title: How Does the U.S. Dollar Influence the World? -Part 1
description: The primary problem in using U.S. dollars is whether to have U.S. dollars in hand, otherwise it would be empty talk.
keywords: U.S. dollar liquidity, U.S. dollar reserve, U.S. dollar.
subtitle: How Does the U.S. Dollar Influence the World? -Part 1
content:
1. U.S. dollar liquidity issues


The primary problem in using U.S. dollars is whether to have U.S. dollars in hand, otherwise it would be empty talk. But for many countries and regions, it is not easy to obtain U.S. dollar liquidity. For example, export products are not competitive, which means that the engine of accumulating dollars is misfired, many countries only have a few dollar reserves. Many import products, especially bulk commodities, need to be priced in USD, creating a contradiction between insufficient USD reserves and unsatisfactory import demand, and this contradiction becomes more prominent when the world financial market is turbulent and capital flows out of some countries. The problem has also prompted many countries to wish to start over and settle trade in bilateral domestic currencies, thereby avoiding the U.S. dollar’s imprisonment of transaction.


In addition, some countries have borrowed a large amount of foreign debt in USD in the international market, and the insufficient USD reserve also causes these countries to default on foreign debts, especially when the foreign debt maturity structure is unreasonable. At the beginning of this year when the pandemic spread across the world, market sentiment suddenly changed, USD liquidity was extremely short, and USD interest rates soared. Many countries faced substantial capital outflows, while foreign debts were due. Lebanon and Argentina had defaulted on foreign debts and the situation of other countries was also precarious. The G20 urgently introduced the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI), and the IMF also provided large-scale loans, which gradually eased the circumstances.


It is also worth noting that if the United States believes that its interests are harmed, it will impose sanctions on market entities and countries that use USD, which will also affect some countries and market entities. Significant influence.
